items.author: Scott Tobias
items.content: It takes enormous skill to pull off such a high-wire act without diminishing the gravity of the situation, but Bong and his first-rate cast are up to the task.

items.author: Michael Atkinson
items.content: It's an altogether remarkable piece of work, deepening the genre while whipping its skin off, satirizing an entire nation's nearsighted apathy as it wonders, almost aloud, about the nature of truth, evidence, and social belonging.
A haunting score and beautifully atmospheric cinematography by Kim Hyung-gu round out the achievements of this unique and engaging Korean thriller.

items.author: Derek Elley
items.content: A powerful, slow-burning portrait of human fallibility.

items.author: Manohla Dargis
items.content: What distinguishes Memories of Murder, setting it apart from rank-and-file thrillers, is its singular mix of gallows humor and unnerving solemnity.

items.author: Frank Scheck
items.content: Uses dark humor, incisive characterizations and social commentary to infuse its familiar detective tale with a distinctive flair.

items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: As exciting for its narrative twists and turns as for its Korean textures and rhythms.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: Becomes something of a rainswept Korean koan on both the nobility and futility of persistence in the face of obviously insurmountable odds.

items.author: Sean Axmaker
items.content: The script is as sloppy as Song's unkempt cop, sprinkled with intriguing ideas and imaginative details that, like the investigation, simply get lost in blind alleys.
